Summary:
The patient is an 87-year-old female with a history of coronary artery disease who presented with NSTEMI and was found to have three-vessel disease (3VD) via cardiac catheterization. She has a stent in the right coronary artery (RCA) placed approximately 10 years ago. The patient declined surgical intervention, and cardiac surgery was consulted, stating that she is a poor surgical candidate.

The patient is currently in the ICU for further management. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C (98.5°F), heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 114/74 mmHg to 152/114 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on a nasal cannula. She is receiving heparin sodium infusion at a rate of 700 units per hour.

The patient's physical examination reveals multiple premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) on telemetry, bibasilar crackles in the lungs, and diminished pulses in both lower extremities. Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), hemoglobin (Hct), and troponin-T levels. Her electrolytes are within normal limits.

The patient's current medications include Plavix, atorvastatin, aspirin (ASA) 325 mg daily, metoprolol 25 mg, and heparin gtt. The plan is to continue these medications, monitor the groin site after cardiac catheterization, and hold angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) due to hypo/normotensive state. The patient is also scheduled for a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) today to assess for RCA territory hypokinesis and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF).

The patient has a history of melanoma and recently underwent excision of right inguinal lymph nodes. She also has a history of dementia, for which she is taking donepezil, and depression and attention deficit disorder (ADD), for which she is taking wellbutrin and methylphenidate, respectively.

The patient's disposition remains in the CCU for now.
